EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Dollar General has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community. The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) dealing with an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure. Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP. In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the
release, and the facility will contact the refrigeration contractor and the fire department for assistance as necessary.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Process Hazard Analysis studies and Compliance Audits have been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system. These studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility. The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment. Dollar General has implemented several action items. In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Dollar General is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities. This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility. For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system. Dollar General has also developed a robust maintenance
program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition. Only trained refrigeration contractors are permitted to perform system operations and maintenance. All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility. In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur. At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.
 
STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
Dollar General took over the responsibility for the facility located at 7101 Hazelwood Ave in Berkeley, MO in 2019. Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for the storage and distribution of grocery products.

The system uses a maximum of 26,200 pounds of ammonia. A description of how the process operates is presented below:

Liquid ammonia in the thermosyphon receiver is fed to the recirculators. The recirculators pump liquid to the evaporators. At the evaporators, air is drawn over the coils by the fans. The ammonia flowing inside the coils is partially vaporized as it absorbs heat from the product and surrounding air. The partially vaporized ammonia is returned to the respective recirculator, where the liquid settles at the bottom of the vessel, while the vapor rises to the top. The vapor in the vessel is pulled off by the compressors. The compressed vapor is discharged to the condensers.
